captions.text: A lot of people say, "I kind of wish you were less coo coo."
A pretty, a pretty, a pretty, a pretty goose for you
And a pretty racing car.
Everyone wants to do it and not think about the bad feces pudding.
What if the world said "nyah, nyah, nyah, nyah"?
Like a parrot, or if a baby got two, uh,
two knick knacks up her sleeve and screamed "mahalo!"
I helped a fuzzy dude cut a piece of fruit,
And when he was chewing on it, I mushed it and called an ambulance.
White men criticize black people over pagers,
and Mexicans will take shoes.
You can give me money, and I'll go make a zoo!
I've got many fake books, since I'm a leprechaun farmer who's a gambler.
Hoo ha! Cherry soda!
I didn't run away. I got a sandwich.
And you'd love it.
I'm Ron Paul!
Everything's blue, baby.
Quick! I want you to hide me!
The Hawaiians think people are idiots
Because we serve peach cobbler and we do it all in a spit cup.
I needed more money and layers of L.L. Bean…
At noon on Wednesday, I'm gonna be leaving a
watermelon pineapple treasure inside of Liam Neeson.
He's the one with the cooked fish allergies.
Give me Vaseline for when I'm having these boring x-rays.
If you refuse, I'll haunt your prostate.
Bam!
That spirit really wants to tap into my whiffle wine.
Let's all pour lotion on the person who thinks I'm an ass,
We should- we should take their wig off!
Like a lot of people, I still drive an SUV.
I'll ride the lightning.
It happened to my kitty, and Elvis was part of it.
Life is murder, and you're forced to fight the war.
You're a pony, and you want this cookie,
and yet you can't think straight.
Bring on the steamed croutons.
I love dishwashers, and if one of my spoons got left,
I'd find the big ape who did it.
The hardest part is to shoot Ramone, I know it.
Dude said, "Have some brewskis!"
and I'm freaking, "Those are awesome, more like it!"
Free bananas!
Ah, well, nevermind.

comments.author: Simon9Mr

comments.text:
+BigExtc  Okay, there's a lot there I'd like to address, but not much time 
to do it, so I'm going to try to see how many birds I can kill with just a 
few well-placed stones..

*"your main premise in your rather well-written reply is that the profit as 
a motivator will make privatized agencies do their job better.  But quite 
frankly, that is not not always the case."*

Well to be fair, there is no way to guarantee that *any* incentive or 
policy will be sufficient to make any given person or agency do their job 
better. What you're proposing is no more of a guarantor of quality, 
integrity or safety for consumers or workers, than is each business's 
natural incentive to remain in the good graces of the public. In fact, what 
you're proposing just amounts to forcibly substituting the whim & 
discretion of politicians, bureaucrats & administrators, for the 
value-judgments & free choices of the general public. That's all it is, in 
the final analysis.

*"In terms of a health care company, whenever you do your job, which is 
provide coverage for health costs, you lose money."*

For one thing, that's by no means necessarily the case. The profits of any 
insurance company are determined just as much by the performance of their 
investment portfolios & the sheer volume of policy-holders, as it is by the 
volume of claims being paid out at any given time.
But in any case, on the subject of insurance, I'll just state right off the 
bat that I am NOT a defender of the status quo, so don't misconstrue 
anything I say on the subject to imply that I am. The US healthcare 
industry is a mess & is in need of serious reform; however, that being 
said, (1) I submit that the reason it's become such a mess is because of 
over half a century of ever-increasing political interventionism, and the 
currently prevailing policies are just further steps in the wrong 
direction; and (2) even with as screwed-up as it's become, the US 
healthcare system is still the envy of the world, regardless of whatever 
the leftist demagogues & statist propagandists may say.

*"arguably, socialized countries like South Korea, the UK, France, and the 
Scandanavian countries have much better health care than us, and they are 
generally government run agencies that are not for profit. "*

I'm glad you were at least sensible enough to say "arguably." That's a 
qualitative judgment, and one that I think is best measured by considering 
how many people from those countries travel to US to receive medical care 
when what they need is the best possible treatment & time is of the essence.
Here's my perspective: There is no such thing as "free healthcare." It goes 
back to the TANSTAFL maxim; there ain't no such thing as a free lunch. 
*Someone* has to pay; whenever human labor-intensive services are involved, 
that implies a *cost.* Even if the policy was effected by enslaving all 
doctors, nurses et al, that would just mean that the entire burden of the 
cost of the system was being shouldered by the enslaved professionals.
All that is implied in the concept of "socialized healthcare," is that one 
part of society should be forcibly held liable for shouldering the burden 
of the healthcare costs of the whole (the costs incurred by the remainder + 
their own); and even amongst the portion of the society which foots the 
whole of the cost, none are considered responsible for their own individual 
expenses, but all are considered responsible for a part of everyone else's.
Now, you may be not be inclined to have any regard for things like 
individual right or responsibility, but you can't just blithely dismiss 
away the fact that when you sever the natural cause-effect relationship 
between a person's decisions & behaviors and the burden of their 
consequences, it's going to create problems. And when we do that as a 
matter of course, as a general, systematized policy, then we just 
institutionalize those problems.
The UK, the Scandinavian "social democracies," the Asian "Peoples' 
Republic" welfare states, are all coming to recognize this. "Reform" is the 
word of the day in those countries, as the reality is becoming clear that 
their profligate welfare state systems were built upon foolish Utopian 
idealism. It's unsustainable & they're all coming around to openly 
recognizing it. This is not to say that abandoning welfare statism as such 
is being widely & openly spoken of in those places; they haven't come to 
that yet. It's going to take a bit longer for them to come around to that. 
For that, many still entertain the notion that the problem isn't one of 
principle, but only one of degree. They're maintaining that their schemes 
were just too ambitious; rather than inherently unsound & foolhardy. But 
even still, they're going to begin moving in the right direction, while 
here in the US, we just continue on our long, blind march down the wrong 
path, on the same Road to Serfdom that F.A. Hayek tried to warn us about so 
many decades ago.

*"He believes scientific biomedical research should be privatized, which to 
me is ludicrous since privatized biomedical research is very much so 
different from independent NIH granted research."*

He believes, as I do, that if the allocation of scarce resources toward a 
given purpose is really so socially-beneficial as to be more urgently 
important than all the potential alternative applications, then it wouldn't 
require the threat of deadly force to accrue the funding & distribute it 
toward that end.
What you're claiming here, is that politicians & bureaucrats are more 
enlightened than ordinary people, and if they aren't empowered to 
expropriate funds from others to have them allocated toward the R&D 
projects that *they* find most important, then society would be deprived of 
the scientific knowledge necessary to solve our most urgent & pressing 
problems.
I just think that's ridiculous.
For one thing, it's not a valid argument to point to given knowledge, 
techniques or available commodities that were funded by government-funded 
research, as a means of asserting that coercive intervention was therefore 
the only way that research & it's benefits could've possibly come about. 
That just begs the question, that's all. You have no way of knowing or 
proving that the funding wouldn't have also come about by voluntary, 
private means in the absence of state intervention, and was simply just 
crowded out by it. It's not as if private philanthropists & benefactors 
don't take these things into consideration!
And in any case, even if it were somehow demonstrable that by government 
intervention was the only way a given R&D project could possibly have come 
about, then all that's saying is that the government removed resources from 
the voluntary sector where they would've been allocated along lines 
believed to best satisfy the most urgent wants & needs of the people in the 
most value-productive way, and instead allocated them along lines most 
favored by a relatively few political elite, their cronies & other 
interested hangers-on.
Do you believe you have some way of demonstrating why the latter should be 
considered inherently any better than the former?
 
*"People got cancer or other diseases.  Sure the company may suffer long 
term profits but the higher ups were already rich by that time, didn't 
matter.  The answer to that is not less government, in that situation, to 
me its more."*

Of course it matters. If people got sick because of the negligence or 
misrepresentation of the facts by others, then the guilty parties should be 
made to pay - meaning they should be "rich" no longer; they should just be 
making their victims rich, if anything.
To me the answer is just common law. Not necessarily "more government," as 
it is just the government doing the one thing that they have any legitimate 
purpose for existing to do in the first place.
Indeed, if the scope & power of government *was* so limited, to just 
protecting peoples' personal & property rights from force or fraud, then 
they would be laser-focused on it, & very efficient. As it is, governments 
are so busy meddling in a hundred thousand different directions, doing 
things they have no legitimate right or authority to be doing at all, that 
they're spread way to thin for us to be able to expect them to do the few 
things that we have a genuinely common need & desire for them to do, on any 
kind of consistent, effective basis.

Okay, I'm out of time, so rant ends now. Hope it had some effect. I'll 
check back tomorrow afternoon; I know there's definitely a few other things 
I wanted to get to, anyhow. Peace, have a good night.
comments.author: Brutus Cassius

comments.text:
+Brutus Cassius
The thing is man, your main premise in your rather well-written reply is 
that the profit as a motivator will make privatized agencies do their job 
better.  But quite frankly, that is not not always the case.
Look at health care, for instance.  In terms of a health care company, 
whenever you do your job, which is provide coverage for health costs, you 
lose money.  And thus, years you make more money, you covered less people. 
 You could say well then switch to another company, let your dollar decide, 
yet these companies by default, by the very nature of their existence 
suffer from the same dichotomies and situations. 
And arguably, socialized countries like South Korea, the UK, France, and 
the Scandanavian countries have much better health care than us, and they 
are generally government run agencies that are not for profit.  
And I'll use another example, science, since I am highly familar with the 
topic.  Ron Paul, to bring this back to him, wanted to heavily cut funding 
to the NIH, which would dramatically reduce independent and privately 
conducted scientific research in both public and private universities 
around the country (incredibly ironic in my opinion).
He believes scientific biomedical research should be privatized, which to 
me is ludicrous since privatized biomedical research is very much so 
different from independent NIH granted research.  NIH funded research is 
typically based on knowing the nature of disease and health, why something 
is the way it is, and looks at all things as possibilities to stop disease 
progression.  Privatized medical industry is focused more on profit than 
actually understanding disease, and there have been SSSSOOOO many instances 
of companies falsifying reports to get their product out faster, at the 
expense of public health.  Even once government found out, the damage had 
already been done.  People got cancer or other diseases.  Sure the company 
may suffer long term profits but the higher ups were already rich by that 
time, didn't matter.  The answer to that is not less government, in that 
situation, to me its more.  
Also privatized medical companies often overlook important things like 
vitamins and their role in disease, as they can't make money off it.  There 
is some money to be made off a supplement here and there, but often times 
the underlying causes of many disease are things that can't be profited 
from.  Also larger studies that track epidemiological trends in populations 
would never be picked up by private research because once again there is no 
money to be made.  How could a company possibly profit from telling the 
public, say eating more red meat leads to higher cancer rates, purely as an 
example.
I think saying private agencies have a lot more to lose is sort of a weak 
argument, IMO at least.  Profit isn't always the primary motivator.  Many 
of the worlds greatest thinkers and innovators get jack-shit in terms of 
financial rewards, yet do their science or thinking simply because they 
love it.  And many great innovations are the product of that.  Also profit 
can get in the way of those doing their jobs correctly, in the case of 
private health insurance agencies.
comments.author: BigExtc

comments.text:
+BigExtc No, the statist comments are not irrelevant, I realize you think 
yourself "moderate," but the fact of the matter is, you clearly buy into 
this notion that it's not enough that the coercive power of government be 
limited to protecting equally the persons & property of all from initiatory 
force & fraud; that we have to acquiesce to arbitrary political authority 
or else we would all be subject to cancer-causing carcinogens in our food, 
water, air, etc, & airplanes would be falling out of the sky in record 
numbers, etc.
In truth, government is composed on self-interested, fallible, corruptible 
human beings just like any other social institution. The only thing that 
really distinguishes the state from any or all other man-made institutions, 
is that it claims & enforces a compulsory monopoly on violence in society. 
And the implications of that enforced monopoly status resonate throughout 
every branch, bureau, and agency of the state, in everything they do. In 
the final analysis, the question we have to ask is, who should we expect to 
have a more powerful incentive to do their level best to ensure standards 
of safety and/or quality are upheld? The people who are employed by a 
compulsory monopoly agency, who need not concern themselves with competing 
firms on the market & who have no real stake in the outcomes? or the people 
who are employed by the firm that stands to suffer legally & financially if 
there is a substantial failure from a safety/quality standpoint?
Consider how it works, as any cursory glance at practical experience will 
show: when there is a financial crisis, the FTC, SEC etc. get *more* money 
thrown at them. When there's an inordinate spike in the numbers of planes 
crashing, the FAA gets more money. If there's an outbreak of e coli, the 
FDA gets more money. So on & so forth. Worse still, many bureaucratic 
agencies constitute inherently self-sustaining fiefdoms, whose interests 
are served by the perpetuation of whatever societal ill it is they're 
ostensibly supposed to be combating. Do you think the army of OT-working 
police, detectives, judges, administrators & bureaucrats who are employed 
in the "War on Drugs" are really in any hurry to *win* that war? Or, say 
you were to give any career welfare-state social worker a button, and told 
them they could eliminate poverty in their community by pushing it, do you 
think that would be an easy decision for them, as it would be for most 
anyone else?
Contrarily though, private accrediting firms & insurance agencies have a 
powerful financial incentive to make sure the firms they associate with 
have effective safety/quality assurance programs. The inspectors & 
administrators who work for Underwriters Laboratories or Better Business 
Bureau have a completely different behavioral incentive structure than 
those employed by the state. The question is, which is more conducive to 
accomplishing the shared stated purpose? And I think it answers itself.
All we can rightfully, & should realistically, expect from any institution 
calling itself "government," is the equal protection of the life, liberty & 
property of all individuals, & courts of civil & criminal law to resolve 
conflict, settle disputes, & exact just restitution for rights-violations. 
And that's about it.
Keep in mind, government is force. When we consider what is the proper role 
of government in society, what we're really considering is what is the 
appropriate role of violence in society. If your answer is anything more 
than the equal defense of the rights of all, then what you're really saying 
is that you repudiate rule of law, and instead just wish to have a safer, 
more convenient means of trafficking in the rights & property of others, 
than by having to do so at your own personal risk.
comments.author: Brutus Cassius

comments.author: femalehero420

comments.text:
+Brutus Cassius
I don't particularly think state is perfectly suited to regulate all 
aspects of life.  But at the same time, I don't think that big business is 
any better suited to do so.  Our government functions on a system of checks 
and balances, and I think that our economic and social issues need that 
same sort of regulation.
I understand your sentiments, that perhaps government is overstepping its 
bounds.  I really do, what with the recent NSA scandal and such things. 
 But I honestly, at the same time, really don't think we should ax the 
government in favor of total free market, I think government might need a 
hedgetrimmer but not the ax.
Free market can be just as corrupt, and has proven to be so on countless 
occassions, and thus there needs to be a counter balance, there needs to be 
an EPA testing water near large factories.  There needs to be an FDA 
testing foods.  Quite frankly there are some things the dollar and consumer 
cannot know about, cannot control and "vote" against with their dollar. 
 Look at the Woburn Mass tannery cancer incident, the Walmart Catawba River 
scandal, to name a few.  
And FYI I am not a socialist, I am quite moderate, so the Statist comments 
are irrelevent.
comments.author: BigExtc

comments.text:
+BigExtc Yeah, well I suggest you not presume to make suggestions, 
especially unless or until you've read up enough yourself to have broken 
out of such a silly caricature of a worldview.
See, here in reality, not only is it entirely conceivable that big business 
& big government could be allied or even symbiotic, but that is in fact 
often the case, In reality, the real thing that concerns politicians & the 
rest of society where they are concerned, is free, contractual & productive 
social bonds, vs. coercive, hegemonic & parasitic social bonds. Ron Paul is 
one of the very few modern legislators, certainly the only one in recent 
memory, who understood that dichotomy, and who demonstrated any *real* 
regard for individual liberty and rule of law.
Also, yes, of course he recognizes that not only is it unconstitutional for 
the federal government to presume to commandeer the security & maintenance 
functions of private airlines, but also that no agencies have a better 
incentive to see to airline safety & security standards than the individual 
airline firms themselves.
But I suppose your one of these True Believers who thinks that the only 
thing compelling commercial airlines to properly maintenance their aircraft 
are government bureaucrats? or that the only reason why the milk you buy 
from the store isn't rotten or swimming with deadly bacteria is because of 
FDA codes?
If that's really how you think, then you're even more hopelessly deluded 
than the average member of the cult of statism. You should probably start 
at the very beginning, and just focus on forming an original thought for 
like 5 or 10 minutes every morning while you're drinking your coffee or 
something, idk.
comments.author: Brutus Cassius

comments.text:
+Brutus Cassius
No, I suggest you read up on what he actually stands for as a politician. 
 The main debate that goes down in congress, the real thing that concerns 
politicians is big business vs. big government.  Do you really think he 
cares about you?
All his policies boil down to small government, big business.  And what 
happens when you take away government regulation and give it all to the 
corporations?  Nothing happens, except that power simply switches over to 
them.  
That is his policy,  He's the one that proposed the "Plan to restore 
America" budget.  Look it up.  In it he wanted to privatize agencies like 
the TSA and FAA, cut funding to all sorts of health and protection 
agencies.  But problems with the TSA and FAA aren't solved when the are 
privatized, they are just become more about profit and the bottom line.
comments.author: BigExtc

comments.text:
+j blin There is a misunderstanding in what Libertarianism is. Chomski is 
referring to modern right-wing Libertarianism which is a purely american 
concept. Ron Paul being an example of a modern Libertarian.The American 
Libertarian party is right-wing libertarian. While still better than 
Conservatism, it is not true original left-wing Libertarianism which is 
what Chomski (and myself) believe we should have. Some people (usually 
American) seem to think that Libertarian Socialism is an oxymoron but that 
is simply because they don't understand how a system could exist outside of 
the tiny wedge of the political compass that America in particular, but 
many other 1st world countries are completely stuck in.
Sure thing, vote Libertarian in the next election. Would still be a welcome 
change from the status quo. However, understand that Libertarians do not 
have to be right-wing, this is just propaganda to make the rich more money 
and to stop people noticing this by giving them more social liberty. Still 
a better system that what exists right now but one that we should be aware 
of the repercussions of and to not get stuck into.
While I am not american, the same thing applies to the UK (my country) as 
well, so nationality is irrelevant here.
comments.author: AliTheAllStar

comments.text:
Oh my! A politician who believes that *gasp* individuals should have the 
right to do what they want with their own bodies! The nerve.

I'm assuming from your comment that you are left leaning and I just have a 
question. Why do all Lefties want to control people so badly? Well, 
Conservatives do too, but in different ways.

I read what you said about murders being caused while high. All the while 
ignoring the fact that far more murders are caused from the underground 
drug market.

If you look at places like San Francisco, who have recently stopped 
enforcing drug laws altogether, murder has actually dropped, significantly. 
Because police resources have been drastically freed up and people don't 
NEED to kill over drug territories and such.

You know what else is dangerous and messes with you mental faculties? 
Alcohol. Do you know what happened when Alcohol was banned here in the US? 
Crime, including violent crime increased because it was sent underground. 
And we are seeing the exact same thing happen with the war on drugs.

But most of all. I'm just pissed that people, both Liberal and Conservative 
alike feel this overwhelming need to FORCE people at the barrel of a 
fucking gun to do what they PERSONALLY believe is right to fellate their 
own self-righteous ego and that sort of attitude is sickening.

Oh and for the record, I do not agree with drug use or promote it in any 
way, but, I believe that people should be allowed to run their lives the 
way they see fit because that is what freedom is and as far as I'm 
concerned freedom is the most important thing on the planet.
comments.author: MemeMasterJackal _

doesn't work that way. You must protect liberty across the board, 
otherwise, the system fails, as it currently is.

comments.author: AnObsoleteMan

comments.text:
Ron Paul was/is a nutjob.  Libertarians who throw away their vote on 
someone who is polling less than 10% in the polls and drawing most of their 
votes from the "R" side are naive fools.  Ron Paul also ran in the "R" 
primaries.  There is where the REAL clout is.  Get out and work for your 
candidate, donate time and money, etc., then if he/she doesn't make the 
cut, vote in the general for the most conservative candidate, be he/she "R" 
or "D", but PLEASE don't waste your vote on someone who hasn't a ghost of a 
chance.  Principle is a great thing, but you toss that "principle" into a 
skillet and saute it up in butter with some onions and you'll wind up with 
nothing but sauteed onions for supper. 
I'd be totally in favor of a 3rd party but now is not the time.  Get out 
there and work for your party between election cycles and when you can be 
competitive then run your best candidate.
comments.author: Tom Wright
